subject: Investing
title: Rent-to-Price Ratios by City
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Rent-to-Price Ratios by City.

hook.text: A house in Cleveland rents for 1.1% of its price monthly. The same ratio in San Francisco is 0.3%.

buildup.text: Rent-to-price ratio divides monthly rent by the property's purchase price to gauge cash-flow potential.

discovery.text: High-ratio cities generate better monthly cash flow; low-ratio cities bet more on appreciation.

twist.text: Chasing the highest ratios can land you in declining markets where tenants are hard to keep.

climax.text: The best strategy balances solid ratios with stable or growing demand in the area.

punchline.text: A high ratio without demand is just cheap property nobody wants.

quiz.question: What does a high rent-to-price ratio indicate?
